Sentence: Dixon has not made a good impression upon the faculty and knows that his (Dixon) superior, the absent-minded Professor Welch, could ask him (Welch) to leave at the end of term next month

Fearful of making further bad impressions or revealing his (Welch) inner disgust for Welch, Dixon agrees to give the end-of-term lecture on the theme of ', "``Merrie England''  (Dixon)', "and to stay with the Welches the following weekend for a weekend of music and the arts
At the party, Dixon meets Welch's son Bertrand and his (Dixon) girlfriend Christine, who have come up to the country from London
Dixon escapes to the pub and returns to the Welches' later that night, where he (Dixon) makes a drunken pass at Margaret Peel, a friend and colleague
Back at the Welches', Christine and Dixon kiss and agree to see each other in two days

Dixon spends the following week planning to write his (Dixon) ', "``Merrie England''  (Dixon)', "lecture in a nostalgic way that will appeal to Professor Welch, but Welch himself keeps Dixon preoccupied with menial fact-checking for Welch's own work
He (Dixon) is drunk when he (Dixon) gives the lecture, and inadvertently imitates the voices of Professor Welch and the college Principal in the opening segments
As they walk down the street, they run into the Welch family, whom Dixon salutes with an explosive laugh of contempt
